I think a certain degree of egotism stirs the Creationism vs. Evolution "debate". 
 
 Evolutions get their rocks off feeling intellectually superior to creationists 
 
 Creationists get their rocks off feeling that the evolutionists are going to hell
 
 With that being said..
 
 What is wrong with America today? Overseas, India and China are granting multitudes more degrees in science and technology than the United States... and in light of this, a large chunk of America is in favor of introducing "intelligent design" into the classroom. This takes an even larger dent out of my already shaky confidence in the direction of this country.
 
 Intelligent Design and Scientific Theory are COMPLETELY SEPARATE things. Some people need religion in their lives and they certainly are entitled to it. After school programs, prayer groups, bible study... its all dandy. But biology? It simple doesn't have a place there.
 
 One of the stone pillars of scientific theory is falsification. Scientific knowledge endures by proving things wrong. Have you ever seen an apple 'fall' upwards? Have you seen anything accelerate without an applied or internal force? No
 
 Nobody else has either; its never been documented, not once, NEVER. This is how science progresses. Its what we gather through millions and millions of falsification experiments (obviously more complicated than my examples). Science is an intricate, vast, quantitative, and beautiful undersanding of the world as we observe it. 
 
 Most proponents of Creationism either blindly reject or simply cannot understand advanced science and mathematics. A huge chunk of Americans believe in creationism while less than 5% of American scientists believe the same. Coincidence? Hardly. It might be condescending, but its true.
 
 To all creationists, or better yet all Christians, I ask you this question:
 
 Imagine you were born on a remote island [lets say your parents were on a cruise ship and a tragic storm tossed you overboard (theoretical here folks)] The very person you are now -- your brain and body -- physically unchanged. The idea here is no religious doctrines are presented to you.
 
 What do you believe?
 
 The answer: Whats around you.
 
 Science is objective, it doesn't have a bias or an agenda. IT ASKS QUESTIONS RATHER THAN SUPPORTS IDEAS. There are over 400 of these established 'ideas' all over the world. What if you picked up a book on Hinduism or Buddism on that island? What makes your idea so special? What makes *you* so enlighted? 
 
 You renounce god and you burn in hell. I know you're scared, but open up some books and free your mind for JC's sake.

 Some of the leaders in the creationist/ID movement are scientifically literate and give sophisticated looking arguments for their position, even though they argue from their own straw man depictions of evolution. Then there are folks like this who post on discussion forums, displaying a total ignorance of science. This post, for example, is so inarticulately written in the language of gibberish that I can't even respond to it. How could I possibly address a question like: "...when do two things happen exactly the same way..." ? I just have to scratch my head and walk away. Then when PoohBear says: "Evolution can't prove itself other than wrong", what can you say to such a self defining assertion? All I can say is: "What is the evidence for creation and how can you test for it?". I'm not holding my breath waiting for an answer to this question.

 To put it in simpler terms, I can't respond to your argument against evolution because you didn't back up your assertion that creation is true & evolution is wrong. Your only evidence against evolution is "God said so". If you want to know how we got here through evolution, you can read a basic text on evolutionary biology and paleontology. No one could possibly explain the whole theory of evolution by natural selection, and cite all the evidence acrued over the past century & a half since Darwin in one post.

Bottom line: 
 
 What this whole thread comes down to is that there's evidence for evolution, physical evidence like fossils and genetics. The only evidence for creation is in the bible, and that probably got changed so many times over hundreds of years that it doesn't even remotely resemble the original text. And even the original text was probably mostly exagerations and metaphors.
 
 So, unless you creationists can come up with some hard core, physical evidence, I'm sticking to evolution.

Phantos: It's far easier I guess to just blatantly believe what some guy with a Ph.D has written than think it through for yourself.

 
 It's BETTER - more logical, more likely to produce correct results, etc. - to believe what a guy with a Ph.D says than for a lay person to come to his own conclusions. Guys with Ph.Ds have spent 8 years in college studying the subject thoroughly and have in-depth knowledge; and through learning the history of the topic, they learn about - and therefore avoid remaking - the mistakes earlier investigators did, before the body of scientific knowledge grew to its present size.
 
 It also BETTER to believe scientific theories than religious myths because scientific findings can be - at least in principle - independently reproduced: they can be objectively verified, unlike religious myths like a talking burning bush, or God creating man from dust and woman from the man's rib, and so on.
 
 
Phantos: It takes a much stronger mind to have blind faith that to believe in science texts, test tubes, and bunsen burners.

 
 Completely wrong! It takes no "mind strength" whatsoever for someone to blindly and unquestioningly accept the religious fables spoken by their leader, which came from the ancient and outdated text created by superstitious and scientifically ignorant people.
 
 It takes a desire for freedom of thought to reject superstition, and it takes great "mind strength" to learn the science of biology (or physics, or chemistry, etc.).

 The thing that irks me the most about the typical creationist (such as Phantos) who posts on these threads, is that they are largely poorly versed in the evolutionary theory they so vehemently try to debunk. There is a certain type of arrogance that is involved here. I would never try to debunk relativity or quantum theory, for example, because I haven't spent the time & energy to study it to the point where I could venture an intelligent opinion on these things. But most of these creationists, who are less familiar with biology than I am with physics, have no qualms about voicing ill informed opinions on the matter. I mean, it's one thing to have an opinion on something, but quite another to argue so stridently against something you are dismally clueless about. DamEtel: Completely wrong! It takes no "mind strength" whatsoever for someone to blindly and unquestioningly accept the religious fables spoken by their leader, which came from the ancient and outdated text created by superstitious and scientifically ignorant people.
 
 It takes a desire for freedom of thought to reject superstition, and it takes great "mind strength" to learn the science of biology (or physics, or chemistry, etc.). 

 
 
Not really. How many things do you believe in that you cannot taste, see, hear, feel, or smell; or for that matter, test.

 
 With some qualifications, none.
 
 I believe in individual atoms (and protons, and neutrons, and so on) even though I can't taste, see, hear, feel, or smell them. Why? Because there are so many different, strong, independent evidences, which are verifiable in principle by anyone, that confirm their existence. 
 
 I don't believe in God or Magical Flying Pink Unicorns and so on because not only can I not taste, see, hear, feel, or smell them, but also because they lack the many different, strong, independent evidences, which are verifiable in principle by anyone, that would confirm their existence. 
 
 Further, without accepting the existence of individual atoms (and protons, neutrons, etc.), most of science - chemistry, biology, physics, and so on - just wouldn't make sense: that is, the WORLD wouldn't make sense. But without God, not only does the world still make sense, it makes MORE sense.

It takes a much stronger mind to have blind faith than to believe in [science]... 

 (my emphasis)
 
 Do you not see the inherent contradiction in this sentence?
